;“这是我们收到的最热烈的接待，”美国人说商人杰夫·鲍曼上个月在中国待了一周。

;

;鲍曼是美国材料科学公司 Cocona 的首席执行官，他独特的纱线吸汗母粒添加剂引起了中国面料的浓厚兴趣

;

;“接待非常热情——看到我们非常兴奋，希望与我们做生意，”鲍曼在美国俄勒冈州的家中说道。

;

; p>;

;他在中国设立了一家外商独资企业，一位客户在最近访问期间甚至达成了一项协议。

;

;Cocona 大约一半的色母粒被运往中国纺纱厂，其中其 1000 万美元至 2000 万美元的公司年收入加上工厂业务中大约有 20% 来自中国 - 这一比例预计只会增长。

;

;鲍曼的故事是美国工业的风向标 - 一堆 -尽管障碍重重。

;

;首先是 2018 年的中美贸易战，然后是华盛顿对技术转让的限制，后来是 2022 年的冠状病毒封锁，以及美国一直呼吁在政治深化的情况下使供应链脱钩。鲍曼补充道：“典型的情绪是，我们希望政府让开，让企业做自己的事。”

;

;美国的工业多种多样，包括电影、坚果等。乳制品和高科技设备也正在绕回中国，意图再次发展业务，尽管在许多情况下，中美贸易和科技战开始时业务有所下降。

;

;他们正在制造在某些情况下，通过向超级富有的客户出售产品，这些客户可以吸收贸易关税上涨造成的价格上涨。

;

;其他人发现，中国需要美国进口产品，因为它无法在国内生产足够的产品，而美国的科技公司标志性的硅谷因其庞大的规模而开始重新探索市场。

;

;中国自 12 月以来在疫情后重新开放尤其促使美国企业重新探索世界第二大经济体，鲍曼等企业家现在可以恢复面对面的访问了。

;

;“在过去 18 个月左右的时间里，我一直在[美国]穿梭，发现并非完全如此，美国的每个人都同意我们不能与中国合作，”前上海美国商会会长、现为旧金山大学常驻执行官的克尔·吉布斯 (Ker Gibbs) 于 6 月中旬表示。

;

;“人们肯定感觉到有问题，但美国人和中国人不是天敌。相反，我们有很多相同的价值观，尤其是在商业方面。”

;

;在贸易争端开始时，加州农业部门的中国业务下降了 30%，但加州大学农业问题中心研究员威廉·马修斯 (William Matthews) 表示，自 2018 年以来，收入小幅上升。

;

;他指出，富裕的中国消费者的需求，加上中国缺乏可用土地来种植足够的粮食他说，中国消费者购买了该州每年价值 20 亿美元的开心果和杏仁作物的一半左右。

;

;加州是美国最大的乳制品生产国，中国进口商正在购买该州的开心果和杏仁作物。马修斯补充道，否则对于国家本身来说，这将是“供过于求”。

;

;“中国一直在进步，”马修斯说，他特别指出了乳制品和坚果。 “在过去的 30 到 40 年里，收入一直在稳步增长，他们想做的第一件事就是改善饮食。

;

;“[该州的种植者]可能会对关税有些不满。 ，但归根结底，加州在以低成本生产优质产品方面非常有竞争力。”

;

;美国前总统唐纳德·特朗普发起贸易战，是因为他认为美国的“不公平”做法中国，包括限制市场准入、盗窃知识产权和强制技术转让。

;

;这场争端已提高了双方价值 5500 亿美元商品的关税。

;

;但 59%中国美国商会受访者在 4 月份的一项调查中表示，他们对中国经济的复苏持积极态度，高于 10 月、11 月和 2 月进行的调查中的 33%。

;

; 2021年，在政治紧张的背景下，中国将允许上映的美国电影公司的电影数量削减了三分之一。

;

;12月，美国政府决定限制与为中国剪辑电影的美国电影公司的合作

;

;美中第一阶段贸易协议是“历史性失败”吗？接下来会发生什么？

;

;来自纽约的导演、编剧兼演员德里克·丁(Derek Ting)几乎没有被吓倒。他拍摄了 2016 年的电影《永远在中国》，并且还会再拍一次。

;

;他在广州的一家医院场地拍摄，并回忆起雇用了“有才华”和“勤奋”的当地修复人员。

;

;他补充道，流媒体电影在中国的观看次数已达数百万次。

;

;丁认为，随着流媒体的兴起，中国市场前景更加广阔，因为网络电影不会受到外国电影公司发行的限制。

;

;他补充说，中国电影院正在从冠状病毒时代的关闭中恢复过来。

;

;“我想每个人都会说这是一个巨大的市场，”丁说。 “如果你有合适的东西，而且他们想要，那为什么不呢？”美国的丹尼·莱文森 (Danny Levinson) 表示，硅谷公司认为现在在中国的投资比 2019 年前“更加忙碌”一家专注于中国的风险投资基金的前技术负责人。

;

;他指出，寻求在美国首次公开募股的中国公司数量有所减少，中国对外国数据公司的“打压”，以及硅谷风险投资公司红杉资本在中国的投资本地化。

;

;莱文森表示，双方“可能处于较长时期的分离之中”。

;

;美中贸易自 2018 年 7 月以来的关键日期和事件的战争时间表

;

;但许多人现在仍然希望在中国扩张，因为这是“一个不容忽视的大市场”，总部位于北京的董事总经理马克·纳特金 (Mark Natkin) 表示市场研究公司 Marbridge Consulting。

;

;“在经历了三年零新冠疫情的艰难时期后，中国的政策制定者 — — 特别是地方政府 — — 仍然非常渴望吸引更多的外国直接投资，”他补充道。

;

;分析人士表示，现在美国企业担心中国工业最终会在竞争中击败美国出口商。

;

;“对于那些在过去 10 到 20 年里一直在努力将其中国业务出售给美国的企业来说，纳特金说：“在竞争日益激烈的环境中，与简单地苦苦挣扎相比，与当地买家换取大笔现金往往是一种受欢迎的选择。”

;

;“中国现在有更多的本土公司，马修斯说，中国农民正在努力种植加州的一些标志性作物，而加州的种植者必须应对不稳定的供水问题以保持竞争力。

;

;美国企业研究所公共政策智库常驻学者德里克·史剑道（Derek Scissors）表示：“中国制造业的市场准入壁垒只是向价值链上游移动。”

;

;“问题仍然是中国只想要外国生产。直到它能够用自己的产品替代外国产品。这是双赢的，直到中国不再需要你。”

;香港应该等到春天才推出垃圾收费计划一个行业组织表示，没有足够的环卫工人来应对圣诞节和农历新年假期预期的需求高峰。

;

;当局计划对政府指定的垃圾袋征收 11 港分的费用。立法会于年底通过2021年《废物处置条例》修订案。

;

;环境服务承建商联盟周五表示，没有足够的人力或时间为该计划的预期目标做准备。该组织表示，“自 2021 年立法通过以来，政府尚未向公众宣传或教育公众有关垃圾收集的任何具体实施模式。” “如果政府坚持在2023年底前实施，我们恐怕无法合作，造成混乱。”

;

;香港餐饮业主加紧应对食物浪费危机< /h3>;

;该联盟代表七个商业集团和约200家公司，涵盖回收和害虫防治等服务。

;

;寒假期间垃圾量将“呈指数级增长”，而该行业组织表示，农历新年假期将造成人力短缺，因为超过 30% 的环卫工人将休假。

;

;“对于该行业来说，招募额外的人力来完成任务是不可能完成的任务。在此期间处理与垃圾税相关的工作。”它说。

;

;这项征税是环保部门提出的一系列措施的一部分，旨在帮助减少家庭产生的垃圾量。

;

;2021年，该市处理了415万吨城市固体废物，其中70%被送往堆填区。

;

;环境生态局局长谢展云多次表示，当局有信心该计划可能会在 2023 年底推出。香港已宣布 18 个月的过渡期，以做好准备。

;

;一位知情人士表示，立法会尚未确定具体启动时间

;

;联盟发言人邱佩林表示，业界必须学习新的废物管理模式，而这需要时间。 “至少我们应该等到四月份人们重返工作岗位时，”他补充道。

;

;政府在启动之前已经遇到了一些挫折，例如环境保护部去年 11 月撤回了该项目的招标。新包包的建议价格“远远超出”了政府的预期。随后于三月份启动了重新招标，并于两个月后结束。

;

;香港必须从源头解决塑料污染，而不是寻求可疑的解决方案

;

;一位发言人周五表示，该部门已收到重新招标期间有45个标书。

;

;“我们已经完成了初步的投标审查，并将把投标审查报告提交给相关部门进行最终批准，”她说。 “我们预计在2023年7月或8月授予所有合同，以期在今年第三季度开始生产指定袋子和指定标签。

;

;“以确保指定袋子有足够的资源我们已要求指定的袋子制造商和物流承办商有足够的能力来满足合同中的额外需求。”

;

;立法会环境事务委员会预计下一步也将讨论该计划周五，预计官员将解释如何实施。

;

;香港环境局长：废物收费计划将于年底生效

;

;该计划的启动将于为期六个月的领养期，在此期间，当局将向公共单位、农村地区和没有业主立案法团的住宅区的 105 万户家庭免费分发袋子。

;

;小组主席伊丽莎白·夸特 (Elizabeth Quat) 表示，重要的是，倡议开始前，包括清洁公司和物业管理公司在内的各方都达成了共识。

;

;环保组织绿色地球执行董事刘志锋表示，联盟提出的一些担忧绿色和平活动人士谭咏琳敦促当局设定准确的开始日期。 “人们很容易拖延。如果政府不能给公众一个日期，就没人会关心这个计划，”她说。

; Sat, 08 Jul 2023 00:20:02 +0800 Just when you thought it couldn’t get any hotter: world breaks record for third time in a weekhttps://www.scmp.com/news/world/article/3226987/just-when-you-thought-it-couldnt-get-any-hotter-world-breaks-record-third-time-week?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.07.08 00:11;
;;

;周四世界记录了有史以来最热的一天，打破了周一创下的历史高点，根据美国国家环境预测中心的数据，周二全球平均气温继续攀升。

;

;据政府机构称，周四全球平均气温达到 17.23 摄氏度（63.01 华氏度） .

;

;这一记录是在美国和中国发生强烈热浪几天后发生的，而随着全球气温飙升，墨西哥的另一场热浪造成100多人死亡。

;

;景星气温接近43.3° C (110°F)，虽然只是异常温暖，如南极洲，但本周整个大陆的气温比正常水平高出 8 华氏度 (4.5°C)。

;

;气温正在上升本周欧洲各地也同样如此。德国气象局 DWD 预计周日气温将达到 37°C (99°F)，卫生部已向弱势群体发出警告。

;

;世界周一将迎来有史以来非官方最热的一天，然后变得更热周二

;

;周四，欧盟哥白尼气候变化服务机构表示，6 月是有史以来最热的月份，大幅打破了 2019 年 6 月的记录。

;

;“这样的记录是气候科学非营利组织伯克利地球的首席科学家罗伯特·罗德在推特上表示：“由于人类温室气体排放，短期厄尔尼诺现象的气温升高加上人类温室气体排放导致的长期全球变暖趋势是可预见的后果。” p>;

;今年厄尔尼诺天气模式出现，给太平洋东部和中部带来温暖的海面温度。

;

;周一首次突破2016年8月的日高点后，几位科学家预计今年将有更多创纪录的日子。

;

;“预计未来还会有更多最热的日子，”孟加拉国国际气候变化与发展中心主任 Saleemul Huq 在一份声明中表示。

;

;科学家、联合国政府间气候变化专门委员会前主席罗伯特·沃森表示，政府和私营部门“并未真正致力于应对气候变化”。他说，公民也不是。

;

;“他们需要廉价能源、廉价食品，但不想支付食品和能源的真实成本，”沃森说。

;

;额外报告美联社。

;美国和中国之间的竞争不是“赢者通吃”美国财政部长珍妮特·耶伦周五表示，全球最大的两个经济体暗示，由于在贸易、技术和台湾等一系列问题上的分歧日益扩大，可能正在酝酿进一步的谈判。

;

;“我们寻求健康的经济竞争，这种竞争不是赢家通吃，而是通过一套公平的规则，随着时间的推移，可以使两国受益，”耶伦在周五与李强总理会面时表示。 “在某些情况下，美国需要采取有针对性的行动来保护其国家安全，在这些情况下我们可能会与中国意见不同。

;

;“但是，我们不应允许任何分歧影响到美国的利益。导致误解，不必要地恶化我们的双边经济和金融关系。”

;

;耶伦补充说，尽管两国存在分歧，但她希望她的中国之行能够“促进两国之间建立更正常的沟通渠道”。

;

; p>;

;中共喉舌中央电视台周五晚间表示，李克强在北京告诉耶伦，中美关系是否“正确”关系到人类的未来。

;

;据报道，李克强还提醒耶伦习近平主席和拜登总统去年在巴厘岛就相互尊重、合作共赢的重要性达成共识。

;

;“希望美方本着务实、理智的态度，中央电视台援引李克强的话说：“与中方共同努力，推动中美关系重回正轨。” “加强合作是现实需要，也是正确选择。

;

;“双方应就重要经济及相关问题坦诚沟通，寻求共识，为中美经济关系注入正能量和稳定性。

;

;中国财政部周五也称耶伦此访是两国元首11月印尼会晤后“落实重要共识的具体举措”。

;

;财政部补充说她此访还将“加强两国在金融领域的沟通与交流”。

;

;中方希望美方采取“实际行动”，为双边经贸健康发展创造良好环境财政部声明称，中美经贸关系是互利共赢的，贸易战和“脱钩”没有赢家。

;< p>;周五早些时候，耶伦在北京会见了美国企业，并向中国美国商会表示，“美中之间稳定和建设性的关系符合美国工人和企业的利益”。

;< p>;“近几个月来针对美国公司采取的惩罚性行动让我尤其感到不安，”耶伦说道。

;

;“我还对中国最近宣布的两种关键矿产实施新的出口管制感到担忧。用于半导体等技术，我们仍在评估这些行动的影响。它提醒我们建立有弹性和多元化的供应链的重要性。

;

;“我已经明确表示，美国并不寻求我们经济的大规模分离。我们寻求多元化，而不是脱钩。世界最大的两个经济体脱钩将破坏全球经济的稳定，而且几乎不可能实现。”

;

;耶伦还呼吁中国转向市场改革，并强调了美国对中国经济的担忧。中国使用“非市场”工具，包括对国有企业和国内企业的补贴，以及对外国企业的市场准入设置壁垒。

;

;美国对中国获取芯片技术的限制旨在耶伦补充说，“目标狭窄”，基于“直接的国家安全考虑”，无意获得对中国的经济优势。

;

;耶伦还会见了央行行长易纲和前经济沙皇据路透社援引一位未透露姓名的美国财政部官员的报道，刘鹤于周五接受了采访。

;

;《华盛顿邮报》上个月报道称，前副总理刘鹤仍定期就重要的金融和经济事务进行咨询 — — 特别是耶伦是继美国国务卿安东尼·布林肯6月修复关系之后访问北京的最高级美国官员，当时他会见了习近平和包括外交部长秦刚在内的高级外交官

;

;据报道，美国气候变化特使克里下周将访华，美国商务部长寄予厚望吉娜·雷蒙多将在北京会见她的同行。

;

; Fri, 07 Jul 2023 23:20:04 +0800 Meta’s Twitter rival Threads tops China’s App Store despite Great Firewall censorshiphttps://www.scmp.com/tech/big-tech/article/3226962/metas-twitter-rival-threads-tops-chinas-app-store-despite-great-firewall-censorship?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.07.07 22:30;
;;

;Meta's new Twitter rival, Threads, is topping China's iOS app charts, despite Western social media apps like Instagram and Facebook being banned in the country by its “Great Firewall”, which regulates the domestic internet.

;

;Threads, launched on Wednesday evening US time, already ranked fourth among free social media apps in Apple's iOS store in China, and just outside the top 50 of all free apps in the country as of Friday. It sat between Chinese tech giant Tencent's QQ Mail and Tencent Video.

;

;The app has gained traction even though users based in China must use virtual private networks to access the platform. According to Greatfire.org, an organisation that tracks online censorship, the domain www.threads.net has been blocked in the country since Tuesday.

;

;While apps such as Twitter and Meta's Facebook and Instagram are downloadable on the iOS app store in China, users in the country cannot access these platform's overseas servers to use their services.

;

;The only government-approved way to launch a foreign social app in China is to develop a locally compliant version with strict content filters, as once attempted by professional networking platform LinkedIn in 2021 with InCareer, before it gave up on its China app earlier this year.

;

;Audio chat app Clubhouse, which briefly became popular in China but never received official approval to operate in the country, was blocked by the Great Firewall in early 2021.

;

;Meta founder and CEO Mark Zuckerberg had tried to get Facebook back into China after it was banned in the country in 2009. But his efforts – which included hosting China's then internet regulator in the Facebook headquarters in 2014 – failed to get Facebook accepted in the mainland Chinese market.

;

;In 2019, Zuckerberg criticised Facebook rival TikTok, run by Beijing-based ByteDance, for censorship. His comments earned him the ire of the official Beijing Daily this week, casting a shadow over any plans that Meta might have in offering its products to Chinese consumers, including its virtual reality gear.

;

;Meta's Threads app functions similarly to Twitter, with text-based posts that can be liked, commented on and shared. Users are able to transfer their followers and user names from Meta's Instagram.

;

;Meta has also announced that it is planning to make Threads interoperable with other Twitter alternatives that are based on open, decentralised social networking protocols, such as .

;

;This could mean that posts from Mastodon servers could be viewed on Threads and vice versa. If Meta follows through on these plans, it could complicate any efforts to comprehensively censor the platform.

;

;While decentralised social media apps like Damus, built on the Nostr protocol, have been removed from China's App Store for including “illegal” content, decentralised social networks have advertised themselves as censorship resistant, due to an ever-expanding network of individually run servers.

;

;Mastodon has also been removed from app stores in China, with a number of its most popular servers blocked in the country. But the network consists of a collection of about 9,000 ever expanding individual servers, with many new and smaller servers often flying under the radar of censors.

; Fri, 07 Jul 2023 22:50:02 +0800 Bosnia’s Serb leader signs controversial law targeting peace envoy, threat to deal that ended civil warhttps://www.scmp.com/news/world/europe/article/3226980/bosnias-serb-leader-signs-controversial-law-targeting-peace-envoy-threat-deal-ended-civil-war?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.07.07 22:09;
;;

;Bosnia's Serb leader Milorad Dodik signed a controversial piece of legislation into law on Friday, according to his office, setting up a potential showdown with the country's international envoy.

;

;The signing of the first of two controversial laws was the latest in a series of inflammatory political moves engineered by Dodik, who has long campaigned for secession from Bosnia.

;

;The Kremlin ally – currently under US sanctions – is president of Bosnia's Serb entity, known as Republika Srpska (RS).

;

;The law signed by Dodik on Friday effectively allows for RS to bypass or ignore decisions made by Bosnia's international envoy, who wields significant executive powers.

;

;Another piece of legislation that suspends RS's recognition of rulings made by the Bosnia constitutional court is waiting to be signed by Dodik, after the RS parliament approved the measure last month.

;

;The laws have been widely condemned in the West, with the United States, United Kingdom and European Union saying the moves threaten a landmark peace agreement that ended the civil war in Bosnia in 1995.

;

;Ex-Bosnian Serb military chief Mladic's genocide conviction upheld

;

;Dodik's signing of the first bill into law comes just days after Christian Schmidt – the top international envoy to Bosnia – struck down the controversial moves by passing an executive order that deems them illegal and prevents their implementation.

;

;Schmidt made the ruling last weekend when he also passed a new measure that would allow Bosnia's judiciary to prosecute politicians who oppose his orders and those of the Constitutional Court – with punishments running up to five years' imprisonment.

;

;As the international envoy, Schmidt oversees the civilian aspects of the peace deal that ended Bosnia's 1992-1995 war, and has the power to sack elected officials and impose laws.

;

;Dodik, however, has vowed to oppose Schmidt. “I am ready to sacrifice and I am ready to go to the end because I have no choice,” Dodik said earlier this week.

;

;Bosnia has been governed by a dysfunctional administrative system created by the Dayton Agreement that succeeded in ending the conflict in the 1990s, but largely failed in providing a framework for the country's political development.

;

;In accordance with the agreement, Bosnia has been divided into two bodies – a Muslim-Croat federation and Republika Srpska. The two entities are connected by a weak central government.

;

;Dodik has held enormous sway over Bosnia's Serb entity for years, and has frequently stoked ethnic tensions and threatened to secede.

;

;The Bosnia Serb leader has also promised to hold a referendum at the end of the year on RS's future status.

;US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen stepped off her plane in Beijing after a long flight from Washington to be greeted by smiles – and a rainbow.

;

;Yellen touched down in Beijing on Thursday afternoon, after a light drizzle in the Chinese capital, greeted at the airport by Chinese finance ministry representative Yang Yingming and US ambassador to China Nicholas Burns.

;

;Chinese reports on Yellen's arrival showed Burns pointing to a rainbow in the sky as she stepped off the plane. Yang then welcomed Yellen with a handshake and was also shown commenting on the heavenly sign while she looked up and smiled.

;

;The friendly reception kicked off a soft opening for Yellen's four-day visit to the Chinese capital, which Chinese social media platforms have studiously observed, including Yellen's down-to-earth cuisine choices.

;

;Asean's US-China defence diplomacy hopes rest on getting its house in order

;

;Yuyuan Tantian, a social media platform affiliated with state broadcaster CCTV, was among the first to post a comment about Yellen's arrival: “With sincerity and mutual respect, Sino-US relations [will improve] just like rainbows after the rain.”

;

;As he welcomed Yellen on Friday, Chinese Premier Li Qiang also mentioned the rainbow. “It's a natural phenomenon … but it also symbolises Sino-US relations. We not only have wind and rain. After experiencing a round of wind and rain, we will definitely see rainbows,” he said.

;

;Li then urged both sides to look ahead in the relationship. “If you only look down at your feet, you can only see muddy roads. But if you look to the sky, you can see the rainbow on the horizon,” he said. In Chinese folklore, rainbows are considered a good omen.

;

;In a Twitter message posted after her arrival, Yellen said the purpose of her trip was to “collaborate on global challenges”, and “communicate and avoid miscommunication or misunderstanding”.

;

;The rainbow connection extended to Beijing's popular Sanlitun shopping and dining district, where Yellen later dined at a top-ranked Yunnan restaurant. Chinese netizens were quick to seize on the symbolism many felt set the tone for the beginning of Yellen's visit.

;

;She was seated in the dining hall instead of a private room – a move deemed by many Chinese netizens as “populist”. The moment was captured by “Panpanmao,” a well-known food blogger on Weibo, China's equivalent of Twitter.

;

;The menu for Yellen and her dinner companions included “very Yunnan-style, home-made” dishes, such as grilled fish with herbs, mint beef rolls, cold rice noodles and various mushrooms, Panpanmao wrote on Weibo.

;

;“I nodded and smiled at her as she walked past my table after dinner, and she returned a bright smile,” the blogger reported.

;

;Yunnan wild mushrooms, famous for their unique taste and fresh fragrance, also come with risks – they can be poisonous or cause hallucinations if they are not properly cooked, or if the wrong varieties are selected.

;

;Yellen, vigorous as ever, appeared to have shown a special interest in mushrooms. The restaurant owner later told local media that the group had ordered four plates of “Jian Shou Qing,” a close relative of the porcini mushroom.

;

;The menu selections also won applause on China's social media platforms, with some users calling the dishes “choice of the Treasury Secretary”, and promising to order the same ones when they visit.

;

;China touts South Korean diplomacy amid anxieties over US engagement

;

;In 2011, then US vice-president Joe Biden visited Beijing and stopped by for local noodles, dumplings, and several platefuls of side dishes in a small eatery called “Yaoji Chaogan.” A photo plastered on the restaurant wall shows Biden smiling with a thumbs-up.

;

;Biden's food choice was later dubbed the “Vice-President's Combo”, and the menu item continues to draw tourists from around the world.

;Below the radar of Washington's highly partisan battles over the US-Mexico border, employment gains for immigrant women in the US are reaching record levels, thanks in part to a surge of Ukrainian refugees.

;

;Many are semi-skilled and highly motivated workers, entering the US legally and through special emergency programmes. They are not only easing intense worker shortages in hospitality, retail and other service industries, but are helping drive up employment for the entire country.

;

;People born outside the US make up just 17.5 per cent of the American working-age population, but foreign-born workers 16 years and older accounted for a whopping 64 per cent of the nation's labour force growth in the two-year period that ended in May, with women making an outsized contribution, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

;

;That compares with a 38 per cent share in the five years to 2019 before the pandemic.

;

;Migrants from abroad have long been an expanding part of the US labour market, offsetting an ageing population and other drags on growth. But their labour participation relative to US-born workers has accelerated further since coming out of the pandemic, thanks to the arrival of hundreds of thousands of refugees, most notably from Ukraine.

;

;Adding to that are emerging social and economic conditions that are driving more immigrant women to work rather than stay at home.

;

;Statistics now show that the labour participation rate of foreign-born women blew past record levels this year and has nearly caught up with that of US-born women, whose numbers are still below pre-pandemic levels.

;

;Desperate and bewildered migrants trapped as US border rules change

;

;“We're already seeing immigration becoming increasingly important in supporting labour force growth, and it will ,” said Julia Gelatt, a senior analyst at the non-partisan Migration Policy Institute.

;

;Beyond filling employers' immediate needs, these newcomers are expected to provide a critical cushion to a US work force hit by both short-term and longer-running forces: and a surge in workers quitting jobs post-pandemic; declining birth rates; and rising deaths, including, suicides and other so-called deaths of despair.

;

;Since Russia's invasion of Ukraine last year, some 300,000 people from that war-torn country have arrived in the US, many under the Biden administration's programme. About 100,000 Afghans have come since the fall of Kabul in late summer of 2021, and tens of thousands more from Venezuela and Cuba, among other countries, are being admitted for humanitarian reasons.

;

;Individuals entering under urgent refugee and parole programmes can secure work permits relatively quickly. They can generally stay for at least two years. Some have come with university degrees and needed skills like nursing. Others are eagerly filling lower-paying openings at restaurants, hotels, retail stores and nursing homes – jobs that US citizens are largely passing up.

;

;Even amid modest economic growth, there were more than 10 million openings in the US this spring – almost two jobs for every officially unemployed person, according to the latest government figures.

;

;Job vacancies were up more than 50 per cent in healthcare and social assistance establishments compared with 2019 before the pandemic, and they were up 22 per cent at lodging and food service businesses, where turnover is rampant. Rough estimates indicate that as many as 50,000 positions that include dishwashing duties may be available, based on job listings in Indeed.

;

;Immigrants make up an especially big part of the work force at hotels and restaurants. Marriott International says it has hired more than 550 refugees in the US since last year. It is one of a dozen companies in lodging, manufacturing, cleaning and other services that have pledged to hire 20,000 refugees over three years.

;

;“We're in a unique moment, politically and economically,” said Yaron Schwartz, the US director for Tent Partnership for Refugees, a non-profit mobilising companies to hire and train refugees.

;

;There are other reasons for the rise in labour participation among immigrant women. Like women overall, those foreign-born are increasingly better educated, which means they're more likely to be working.

;

;Economic pressures also are pushing traditional immigrant households to put stay-at-home mums into outside work, especially given the last couple of years of high inflation.

;

;“It's almost a necessity,” said Naomi Cruz, a Glendale immigration lawyer who had been the LA lead at the Latinista, a group promoting careers and entrepreneurs among Latinas.

;

;Nearly one-third of Latinos in the US are foreign-born. In more recent years Asia has been the leading source of immigrants, and among women, Census Bureau statistics show that those from India have seen the biggest employment gains, likely reflecting more spouses of tech workers with H-1B visas in the job market.

;

;Jill Biden visits Ukrainian refugees, calls them 'amazingly strong'

;

;Overall, net immigration to the US, including refugees, exceeded 1 million between 2021 and 2022. That was more than double the number in each of the prior two years, when the pandemic and other border-tightening policies under the Trump administration brought international migration to a decades low.

;

;Experts don't expect such big increases in immigration in the years ahead because of caps under US law, but various humanitarian programmes allowing a month from Venezuela, Cuba, Haiti and Nicaragua, are likely to continue to boost the numbers.

;

;These and others from abroad are expected to become increasingly important for the labour force as the US joins other advanced economies caught in a demographic squeeze.
